Fig. 1 Synthesis roadmap of Ru-Ce/NC catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Schematic diagram of reaction device and detection device. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, (b) pore size distribution of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a-b) SEM images, EDX element mapping images ((c) field of view, element distribution images of (d) C, (e) N, (f) O, (g) Ru, (h) Ce), (i) EDX analysis of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TEM images of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 (Red: the lattice fringe of Ru nanoparticles, and Yellow: the lattice fringe of CeO2). Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) full-scan XPS spectra, (b) C 1 s fine spectra, (e) O 1 s fine spectra, and (f) N 1 s fine spectra of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600, (C) Ce 3d fine spectra of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 and Ce/NC170–600, (d) Ru 3p fine spectra of Ru/NC170–600 and Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) the effect of carbon precursor synthesis temperature on catalytic performance (carbonization temperature: T = 600 °C Ru/CeO2 = 1: 0.1); (b) the effect of Ru/CeO2 molar ratio on catalytic performance (carbon precursor synthesis time: t = 6 h, carbonization temperature: T = 600 °C); (c) the effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performance (carbon precursor synthesis time: t = 6 h, Ru/CeO2 = 1: 0.05). Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a-b) SEM images of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–500, (c-d) SEM images of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600, (e-f) SEM images of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–700, (g-h) SEM images of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–800. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Effect of (a) reaction temperature (RT = 4 h, PO2 = 2 MPa), (b) retention time (T = 140 °C, PO2 = 2 MPa), (c) oxygen partial pressure (T = 140 °C, RT = 4 h) on the catalytic performance of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalysts, and (d) dosage of BA (T = 140 °C, PO2 = 1 MPa, and RT = 4 h). Fig 9 Fig. 10 (a) Recycling performance of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst (the cyclic experiments were carried out under optimized reaction conditions); (b) XRD patterns of the used catalyst; (c-d) SEM images of the used catalyst. Selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes by molecular oxygen is one of the most important transformations in multiphase catalysis. In this paper, a catalyst with selective oxidation ability was designed and synthesized for the selective catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. N-doped carbon materials were prepared by high-temperature calcination using hydrothermal reaction products of citric acid and melamine as a carbon source, and a bimetallic catalyst supported by Ru-CeO2 was constructed using the mixture as the carrier for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The results showed that the introduction of CeO2 could effectively improve the oxidizing ability and catalytic activity of the catalyst. The Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst was able to convert 85.5 % benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde at 140 °C, 6 h, and 2 MPa, and the selectivity for benzaldehyde was 100 %. It was demonstrated by DFT that it was theoretically feasible to generate benzaldehyde by extracting hydrogen atoms from benzyl alcohol molecules. Further, the selective oxidation experiments on other alcohols showed that the catalyst has high activity for the oxidation of various alcohols to generate the corresponding carbonyl products, and it is a catalyst with broad-spectrum selective oxidation ability. In this study, a green synthesis route of benzaldehyde was proposed to solve the problems in the traditional process. Meanwhile, it provides a new idea for the synthesis of carbonyl products by selective oxidation of alcohols. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bimetallic catalyst Selective oxidation Benzyl alcohol Synergistic effect Mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Benzaldehyde (BD), as an important fine chemical intermediate, is commonly used in the preparation of chemical products such as dodecanal, dodecanoic acid, 2-phenylacetaldehyde, and benzyl benzoate [1,2]. Therefore, the industrial synthesis of benzaldehyde is of great significance in the manufacture of fine chemicals. In the traditional production process, chlorinated hydrolysis of toluene gives low yield and poor selectivity for benzaldehyde [3]. This synthesis route produces a variety of harmful by-products during the reaction process, resulting in chlorine pollution [4,5]. At the same time, the by-produced hydrogen chloride is very easy to cause equipment corrosion, which increases the maintenance cost [3]. The liquid-phase oxidation of toluene must be strictly controlled reaction conditions. This is attributed to the fact that in the presence of oxygen, benzaldehyde is more susceptible to oxidation than toluene, leading to the peroxidation of benzaldehyde into benzoic acid [6]. To solve the above problems in the production process, the development of efficient and green synthesis routes for benzaldehyde has become an urgent problem in current research. The selective oxidation of alcohols to the corresponding aldehydes by molecular oxygen is one of the most important transformations in multiphase catalysis and also a challenging reaction in green chemistry [7-9]. Selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol has been proposed as an alternative method for the production of chlorine-free benzaldehyde. Therefore, the key to an efficient and green synthesis route is the development of a catalyst with high activity and selectivity to minimize the generation of by-products and improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde [10]. Transition metals such as Co, Ni, Mn, and Cu have been widely used in the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol in recent years due to their low price [11-15]. Ali et al. [16] used copper-manganese oxides as catalysts for benzyl alcohol selective oxidation using molecular oxygen as oxidant. The copper-manganese oxides were active in catalyzing the reaction, but the activity varied widely. This was attributed to the limited activity of transition metals for benzyl alcohol oxidation. Researchers have begun to turn their research direction to precious metals (e.g., Ru, Pt, Pd, and Au) [17-20]. Precious metals have high catalytic activity in the oxidation process, and also show better stability, possessing properties such as high temperature resistance and oxidation resistance [21]. According to the report [22], Ru(III) cations are active in the oxidation of various alcohols to produce the corresponding carbonyl products. On hydroxyapatite-loaded Ru catalysts with Ru(III) cation coordinated to four oxygen and one chlorine as the active sites, the oxidation of 1-octanol gave 94 % yield of 1-octanol without the formation of carboxylic acids and esters. In contrast to ruthenium-based metal complexes, Ru(III)/hydroxyapatite effectively catalyzed the oxidation of alcohols containing N and S heteroatoms to form the corresponding aldehydes. Although metal Ru is highly active for the oxidation of hydroxyl groups to carbonyls, its selectivity for the target products in the catalytic oxidation reaction is not high [23]. There is a positive synergistic interaction between Ru and CeO2 and the interaction is present only for metal Ru. Therefore, the lattice oxygen storage capacity and high oxygen transfer capacity of Ce can be used as a catalyst additive to improve the selectivity of the catalyst to benzaldehyde [24-26]. In addition to the active center, the carrier is of great significance for the selective oxidation reaction of benzyl alcohol. Carbon materials are commonly used as catalysts or catalyst carriers due to their large specific surface area, high mechanical, chemical stability, and strong resistance to acids and bases [27,28]. In general, specific surface properties of carbon materials are necessary for their application. The introduction of heteroatoms changes the charge distribution, which in turn affects the redox behavior of surface functional groups in heteroatom-doped carbon materials [29-32]. Therefore, heteroatom-doped carbon materials are considered to be excellent candidates for catalysts and carriers and have attracted much attention. N-doped carbon materials have gained attention in recent years due to the proximity of the atomic radii of nitrogen and carbon atoms [33]. However, few reports have proposed the application of N-doped carbon materials in alcohol selective oxidation reactions. N-doped carbon materials not only possess the advantages brought by the carbon material itself but also N with the surface structural defects of the catalyst itself has high selectivity for the oxidation of aromatic alcohols [34]. It is favorable to improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. In addition, the well-developed porosity is advantageous for carbon materials used as carriers because the porous structure facilitates diffusion and mass transfer between the catalyst and reactant molecules [27]. Therefore, in this paper, N-doped carbon materials loaded with Ru-CeO2 bimetallics were prepared by the impregnation method for use as selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol for the preparation of benzaldehyde. The effects of different catalyst synthesis conditions and reaction conditions on the catalytic performance were examined, and the thermal stability of the catalysts was evaluated. Possible reaction sites were identified, and a possible reaction mechanism was proposed to give a possible theoretical explanation. A novel catalyst and a green and economical process pathway were provided for the preparation of benzaldehyde by multiphase catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Melamine (C3H6N6, 99 %), citric acid (C6H8O7, 99 %), anhydrous ethanol (C2H6O, 99 %), benzyl alcohol (C7H8O, 99 %), benzaldehyde (C7H6O, 99 %), benzoic acid (C7H6O2, 99 %), and acetonitrile (C2H3N, 99 %), all of the above reagents were purchased from the Sinopharm Shanghai Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Ruthenium trichloride (RuCl3, 99 %) and cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3, 99 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. The above drugs and reagents do not require further purification before use. All the ultrapure water used in the experiments and operations was purchased from Hangzhou Wahaha Group Co., LTD., Zhejiang, China. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of N-doped carbon materials In a typical synthesis process (Fig. 1 ), a certain amount of melamine, citric acid, and 30 mL of deionized water were mixed, stirred thoroughly for 2 h, and then transferred to a high-pressure hydrothermal kettle equipped with 100 mL of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) lining. After hydrothermal reaction at a certain temperature (110–190 °C) for 6 h, the product was washed and filtered. The product was dried in a drying oven at 120 °C for 24 h. The dried product was placed in a tube furnace and carbonized in an N2 atmosphere at a certain temperature (600–800 °C) for 2 h (heating rate of 5 °C‧min-1) to produce N-doped carbon materials. The N-doped carbon materials obtained by high-temperature carbonization were washed several times with deionized water and dried at 120 °C for 24 h to obtain the purified N-doped carbon materials. 2.2.2 Impregnation method to prepare supported catalysts The supported catalysts were prepared by the improved impregnation method. N-doped carbon materials synthesized by the method described in Section 2.2.1 were used as the carrier of the supported catalysts, which were impregnated with a certain volume of 0.02 mol‧L-1 RuCl3 solution and Ce(NO3)3 solution configured in advance and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The solvent is removed by spinning and the impregnated material is further dried. The impregnated materials were filtered and dried. The materials were reduced at 350 °C for 2 h under H2 atmosphere (temperature increase rate 5 °C‧min-1) and recorded as Ru-Ce x /NCy-z, where x is the molar ratio of CeO2 to Ru, y is the carbon precursor synthesis temperature, and z is the carbonization temperature. 2.3 Characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts were tested using a specific surface area and porosity analyzer (ASAP 2010, Micromeritics) to give Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution data for the catalyst materials. The crystal structure of the sample was tested by X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). Test parameters: scanning speed: 2 °‧min-1, scanning angle: 10–80 ° X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data of the catalysts were tested using a Thermo Fischer Scientific Escalab 250 XI device, giving the types of elements contained in the materials and their valence states. The surface morphology and microstructure of the catalysts were analyzed using a Hitachi scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800). The corresponding EDX elemental mapping images (mapping) of the material were tested by an energy spectrometer, giving the distribution of typical elements in the catalyst. The catalysts were analyzed for morphology and pore structure using a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F) from Nippon Electron Co. The amount of metallic Ru and Ce leaching was provided by Agilent 5110 inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). 2.4 Selective catalytic oxidation experiment The reaction of selective catalytic oxidation of BA to synthesize benzaldehyde was carried out in a micro stainless-steel reactor (MS50-P3) lined with PTFE. The volume of the PTFE liner was 35 mL. The reaction setup and detection apparatus are shown schematically in Fig. 2 . In a typical oxidation experiment, 0.05 g of catalyst, 0.1–0.5 mL of BA, and 10 mL of acetonitrile were added. After the reactor was sealed, N2 was introduced to regulate the initial pressure in the reactor to check for leaks. After the heating jacket was warmed up to the set temperature, it was filled with O2 at a preset pressure, the magnetic stirrer was turned on, and the catalytic experiment started. At the end of the reaction, the reaction was quenched to room temperature. The post-reaction solution was filtered through a 0.22 μm organic-based microporous membrane for final analysis. The catalyst was collected, washed, dried processed, and recycled by hydrogen reduction. A gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014C) was used to determine the amount of reactants (benzyl alcohol) and products (benzaldehyde and/or benzoic acid) in the reaction solution and to calculate the conversion of BA (C BA) and selectivity of BD (S BD). The procedure was calculated by the internal standard method using n-dodecane as the internal standard. Hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID) temperature: 220 °C, gasification chamber temperature: 220 °C. Column temperature program: hold at 100 °C for 6 min, ramp to 150 °C at a ramp rate of 20 °C‧min-1, hold at 150 °C for 1 min, ramp to 180 °C at a ramp rate of 30 °C‧min-1, hold at 180 °C for 1 min, and finally the temperature was increased to 220 °C at a rate of 20 °C‧min-1. Carrier gas: N2, injection volume: 1 μL. The conversion of benzyl alcohol (C BA) and the selectivity of benzaldehyde (S BD) are calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2) as follows: (1) C BA ( % ) = C 0 − C t C 0 × 100 % (2) S BD ( % ) = C BA C 0 − C t × 100 % where, C 0 , the initial concentration of benzyl alcohol in the reaction solution, mg‧L-1; C t , the concentration of benzyl alcohol in the reaction solution after reaction t h, mg‧L-1; C BA , the amount of benzyl alcohol corresponding to the consumption of benzyl alcohol for the generation of benzaldehyde after reaction t h, mg‧L-1. 2.5 Theoretical calculation In this paper, the geometrical structure of the reactant/product molecules was first optimized at the B3LYP/6–31G(d, p) level using density functional theory (DFT). Frequency calculations were performed to determine that the optimized structures were global minima with no imaginary frequencies. Reaction sites were predicted based on the van der Waals surface electrostatic potential (ESP) and the average local ionization energy (ALIE) complementarity [35]. At the B3LYP/6–31G(d, p) level, the transition state structure was searched by the TS method while frequency calculations were performed to ensure that there was only one imaginary frequency. The structures of the reactants/products were obtained from the endowment reaction coordinates (IRC) calculated at the B3LYP/6–31G(d, p) level, which were further geometrically optimized to obtain accurate structures. The IEFPCM model was used to consider the solvent effect. Molecular optimization and frequency calculations were performed using the Gaussian 16 program, visualization was done by GaussView 6.0, Multiwfn 3.8 and VMD, and other calculations were done by the quantum chemical calculation program Multiwfn 3.8 [36]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of different catalysts. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalyst exhibited typical type IV isotherm characteristics (Fig. 3a). Having a typical narrower H3 type hysteresis loop, which may be related to the catalyst sheet structure, needs to be further proved by SEM images. According to the pore size distribution graph in Fig. 3b, when the carbonization temperature is low (500 °C-600 °C), micropores and smaller mesopores predominate; further increasing the temperature, the proportion of mesopores and macropores increases rapidly. The data shown in Table 1 strongly support these inferences. This may be due to the collapse of voids as the carbonation temperature increases. It indicates that the Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst has an abundant pore structure, which provides a large number of binding sites for the active center. In addition, the abundant pore channels are also conducive to the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules, which promotes the catalytic reaction [28]. It can be seen from Fig. S1 that the XRD patterns of samples before and after loading are very similar. The diffraction peaks at 27.5 ° and 43.6 ° can be well attributed to the (002) and (100) crystal faces of the CN structure, respectively [37]. The characteristic peaks belonging to Ru or CeO2 species were not observed, which can be attributed to their weak loading and high dispersity. The morphological features of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 were observed by SEM. The SEM images shown in Fig. 4 a-b indicate that the catalyst has a lamellar structure consisting of a combination of smaller coral-like structural units. Further observation of the coral-like lamellar structural units reveals that they are not smooth, but rather have a concave and undulating structure. The above structure provides the catalyst with a rich pore structure and improves the specific surface area of the catalyst. The larger specific surface area and complex pore structure provided more binding sites for the loaded metals, which promoted the catalytic reaction. The EDX elemental mapping images (Fig. 4c-h) show that several elements, C, N, O, Ru, and Ce, are uniformly distributed. Among them, the distribution of the two metals, Ru and Ce, on the catalyst is consistent with the distribution of the element O. The density of Ru and Ce elements is also relatively high in areas with a high density of O elements. This may be related to the ability of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of carbon materials to capture and anchor active metals. The uniformly dispersed O and N elements promote the uniform and tight binding of the metals Ru and CeO2 to the N-doped carbon supports. According to EDX analysis (Fig. 4i), the content of Ru and Ce in the catalyst is slightly lower than the theoretical loading due to the limitation of impregnation method. Combining Figs. 4 and 5 a, it can be observed that the surface of the synthesized catalyst has a concave structure. this structure may be related to the lamellar structure formed by the combination of coral-like structural units mentioned earlier. The interlocking coral-like structures are implicated in restricting each other, which increases the stability of the material and facilitates the adaptation to high-temperature and high-pressure reaction conditions. In addition, the structure provides abundant pore channels, which provide more binding sites for the active centers and a large number of pores for the adsorption of reactants during the catalytic reaction. Fig. 5b shows the lattice stripes of the catalyst surface-loaded metal at a 2 nm scale. The red color is the lattice stripe of Ru nanoparticles and the yellow color is the lattice stripe of CeO2. Fig. 5c gives the lattice fringes of Ru with a lattice spacing of d = 0.21 nm, which belongs to the Ru (101) crystal surface [28]. Fig. 5d gives the lattice streak of CeO2 with lattice spacing of d = 0.31 nm, which belongs to the CeO2 (111) crystal plane [38]. It further indicates that the Ru-CeO2 bimetallic catalyst was successfully synthesized. In addition, it can be found on the TEM image that the positions of Ru and CeO2 are closely connected, which provides a short mass transfer distance for the adsorption and activation of benzyl alcohol during the reaction process. To better understand the elemental composition and valence states in the catalysts, the catalysts were analyzed by XPS (Fig. 6 ). With reference to the binding energy position of C 1 s fine spectra in Fig. 6b, contaminated carbon was selected as the internal standard to correct XPS data. The fine spectra of C 1 s can be deconvolution into three peaks corresponding to the CC bond (284.78 eV), CO/C = N bond (286.25 eV,), and C = O bond (287.78 eV) [39-41]. Fig. 6a shows the full-scan XPS spectra of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600, where peaks belonging to the elements C, O, N, Ru, and Ce were identified, respectively. The presence of the N element indicates that the N element is successfully doped into carbon material during catalyst synthesis. The presence of the binding energy peaks of Ru and Ce indicates that Ru and CeO2 are successfully loaded onto the catalyst. The peak signal of Ce is weak because the load of CeO2 is low. Fig. 6a further confirms the successful synthesis of the Ru-CeO2 bimetallic catalyst. The XPS fine spectra of Ce 3d of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 is shown in Fig. 6c. Three peaks (U1, U2, and U3) with binding energies in the range of 875 eV-890 eV belong to Ce 3d5/2, and four peaks (V1, V2, V3, and V4) with binding energies in the range of 895 eV-915 eV belong to Ce 3d3/2 [42]. In the fine spectra of Ce, U2 and V3 correspond to the Ce3+ state (accounting for 29.21 % of cerium species, Table S1), indicating the presence of oxygen vacancy (VO) in CeO2[43]. VO can act as an electron trap to promote oxygen chemisorption and molecular O2 activation, which facilitates the oxidation of BA [43,44]. In addition, it can be found that Ce element has a weak signal intensity and obvious noise in the XPS test, which may be attributed to the small loading of CeO2 on the catalyst, uniform dispersion on the catalyst surface, and good dispersion. It is consistent with the SEM-mapping results. Fig. 6d shows the Ru 3p fine spectra of the Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst. Since the position of the C 1 s peak overlapped with that of the 3d5/2 peak of Ru 3d, we chose the peak of Ru 3p for the analysis [45]. There were two peaks of Ru 3p near 462.26 eV and 484.51 eV, corresponding to Ru0 3p3/2 and Ru0 3p1/2 [46]. Compared with that of Ru/NC170–600, the characteristic peak positions of Ru0 3p3/2 and Ru0 3p1/2 in Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 are negatively shifted (Δ = 0.19 eV). The shift of the Ru° characteristic peak positions towards lower binding energies suggests that there is an interaction between Ru and CeO2. In bimetallic catalysts, there is electron transfer between Ru and CeO2 and/or Ru and the carrier. CeO2 has electron-donating properties that increase the electron density of Ru nanoparticles, which also suggests that the electronic interactions between the Ru active site and CeO2 inhibit the formation of Ru oxides [47]. In addition, Ce has good oxygen storage and oxygen transfer capacity, making it a reliable catalyst additive [25]. Combined with the evidence given by TEM, the positions of Ru and CeO2 are closely linked. The experimental data shown in Table 2 further proved that there was a positive synergistic effect between Ru and CeO2 in this bimetallic catalyst, which was conducive to the improvement of the catalytic performance. XPS identification showed that many kinds of O coexist in O 1 s fine spectra, and the peaks with binding energies located near 531.04 eV, 532.18 eV, and 533.34 eV belonged to lattice oxygen, chemisorbed oxygen, and surface-OH, respectively (Fig. 6e) [48]. The lattice oxygen content was slightly increased in Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 compared to Ru/NC170–600 (Table S2), which was attributed to the increase in lattice oxygen content due to the introduction of CeO2. According to the report, more lattice oxygen on Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 was transferred from CeO2 to the vicinity of the Ru active site and involved in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol, with promoting the oxidative removal of hydrocarbon, hydrogen species from the Ru catalytic site to regenerate the fresh catalytic surfaces, and preventing deactivation of the catalyst [49]. Fig. 6f shows the N 1 s fine spectra of the Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst. The fine spectra of N 1 s are deconvolved into three peaks at the binding energy of 398.42 eV, 399.42 eV, and 400.49 eV respectively [50,51]. According to the literature reports, the peaks of pyridine-N, pyrrole-N, and quaternary-N (graphite-N peak) respectively correspond to these peaks [40,41,52]. This also proves that N has been successfully introduced into carbon materials. Doped N facilitates the activation of reactant molecules, e.g., carbon atoms adjacent to graphitic nitrogen are “metal-like” and can activate oxygen to form reactive species through spin and charge polarization. In addition, defective structures on N-modified carbon carriers (e.g., edge carbons) can create dangling σ-bonds, leaving π-electrons unrestricted and facilitating electron transfer [53]. In conclusion, a synergistic Ru-CeO2 bimetallic catalyst was designed and synthesized for the selective catalytic oxidation of alcohols for the preparation of the corresponding aldehydes. The interaction between Ru and CeO2 enhanced the stability of the catalysts, and the electron transfer modulated the pro-oxidant ability of the bimetallic catalysts. 3.2 Evaluation of catalyst performance 3.2.1 Optimization of catalyst synthesis conditions To explore the optimum preparation conditions of the catalyst, the synthesis temperature of carbon precursor, the molar ratio of CeO2 to Ru, and the carbonization temperature were investigated by the control variable method. The carbon precursors were synthesized at different temperatures to prepare catalysts, and then the selective oxidation of BA was carried out (Fig. 7 a). The relationship between BA conversion and carbon precursor synthesis temperature was “volcano type”. Before 170 °C, the conversion of BA tends to increase as the synthesis temperature increases, and the conversion of BA is positively correlated with the synthesis temperature; after 170 °C, the conversion of BA decreases as the temperature increases further, and the conversion of BA is negatively correlated with the synthesis temperature. Interestingly, for selectivity, the selectivity to BD was 100 % regardless of the synthesis temperature. Therefore, the optimum synthesis temperature for the catalyst is 170 °C. The material synthesized at 170 °C was used as the carbon precursor and the carbon material synthesized by carbonization at 600 °C was used as the carrier. Catalysts with loading molar ratios of Ru/CeO2 = 1: 0.05, 1: 0.1, and 1: 0.2 were prepared, respectively. The results of the selective oxidation experiments of BA are shown in Fig. 7b. From the figure, it was shown that the conversion of BA showed a decreasing trend with the increase of CeO2, and the conversion of BA was negatively correlated with the content of CeO2. The increase of CeO2 formed an inhibitory effect on the activity of the catalyst. According to the literature, CeO2 as a catalyst additive can improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst, whereas the presence of CeO2 in this paper rather decreased the activity of the catalyst. Therefore, the performance evaluation of Ru catalysts was added. It is easy to see from Fig. 7b that the bimetal can effectively improve the catalytic activity. We believe that CeO2 still acts in the catalyst to improve the activity, and the presence of a small amount of CeO2 can greatly improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst. This result is the same as reported in the literature and confirms the experimental principle that there is a positive synergistic effect between the metals Ru and CeO2, and the catalytic effect of the bimetallic catalyst is better than that of the single metal Ru. The increase in the content of CeO2 leads to the decrease of the catalytic activity because the CeO2 covers the active metal Ru, resulting in the decrease of catalytic performance of the catalyst. It is more noteworthy that the selectivity of benzaldehyde remains 100 % under the variable of metal loading ratio. It can be seen that the optimal metal loading ratio is Ru/CeO2 = 1: 0.05. The effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 7c. The conversion rate of BA increase and then decrease with the increase of the calcination temperature. The calcination temperature is negatively correlated with the conversion rate of BA. This may be attributed to the increase of calcination temperature resulting in the collapse and blockage of catalyst channels (Fig. 8 ), which reduced the specific pore volume and specific surface area of the catalyst, resulting in changes in the pore structure of the catalyst, resulting in poor catalytic performance of the catalyst. When the carbonation temperature is low (500 °C), coral-like sheet structural units begin to form (Fig. 8a-b). When the temperature rose to 600 °C, the sheet structure was further carbonized, the number of coral-like sheet structural units increased, and the porosity increased (Fig. 8c-d). When the carbonization temperature was further increased, it was found that the surface of the material tended to be smooth, the collapse degree of the material structure increased, and the blockage degree of the pore increased (Fig. 8e-h). It can be seen that the optimum calcination temperature of the catalyst is 600 °C. In summary, the catalytic properties of Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 prepared at a synthesis temperature of 170 °C, a loading ratio of Ru/CeO2 = 1: 0.05, and a calcination temperature of 600 °C were optimal. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction conditions on catalytic performance Reaction temperature (T), residence time (RT), and oxygen pressure (PO2 ) are important factors that affect the catalytic oxidation performance. Therefore, we conducted experiments on several important factors that affect catalytic performance (Fig. 9 ). As shown in Fig. 9a, when the reaction temperature is low, the conversion rate of BA increases rapidly with the increase of reaction temperature; when the reaction temperature further increases and reaches the bottleneck of BA conversion rate growth, the BA conversion rate is 86.0 %. Meanwhile, when the reaction temperature is low, the selectivity of BD is 100 %; When the reaction temperature is too high, BA is oxidized to benzoic acid. This is because during the catalytic oxidation process, BA is first oxidized to BD. Increasing the reaction temperature and prolonging the residence time may lead to peroxidation, which oxidizes the generated BD to benzoic acid. According to Fig 9b, at a certain reaction temperature and oxygen partial pressure, the conversion rate of BA increases with the prolongation of retention time. After reaching 6 h, continue to increase the reaction time, and the conversion rate of BA remains unchanged. As the reaction time progresses, the selectivity of BD remains at 100 %, proving that the reaction is a fundamental reaction and does not involve complex reaction processes. In this process, it is only necessary to control the reaction conditions to prevent the formation of benzoic acid through peroxidation, which can effectively control the selectivity of BD. The effect of pressure on BA conversion is relatively small (85.7 %−86.0 %) (Fig 9c), as oxygen is excessive, avoiding the impact of insufficient oxygen on catalytic oxidation. After optimizing the reaction conditions, we investigated the effect of the number of reactants on the catalytic performance (Fig 9d). We found that the maximum concentration of BA oxidation exists in this catalytic system. When the amount of BA continues to increase, the conversion rate of BA decreases. In addition, we have supplemented relevant experiments on the influence of catalyst amount on reaction performance. Firstly, the catalyst amount was preliminarily determined to be 5 g‧L-1 according to the catalyst dosage reported in literature. On this basis, the experiment of the influence of the amount of catalyst on the reaction performance was discussed (Fig. S2). According to the experimental data, the conversion rate of BA is limited when the amount of catalyst is low (2.5 g‧L-1), which may be attributed to the insufficient number of active centers. When the amount of catalyst was increased, the conversion rate of BA was increased. However, when the amount of catalyst was further increased, the conversion rate of BA remained basically unchanged. The selectivity of BD was 100 % under this reaction condition. In Table 3 , compared with literature reports, although the reaction temperature is higher and the retention time is longer, the catalytic system has a higher conversion rate to BA (85.5 %) and a higher selectivity of BD (100 %). For the reaction, the 100 % selectivity of BD maximizes the yield of the target product, avoids additional operations due to by-product separation, and reduces production costs. For reactants that are not fully converted, the conversion rate can be increased by recycling the feedstock. 3.2.3 Cyclic experiments We evaluated the cycling stability of the Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst through five cyclic experiments. In a typical cycle experiment, the filtrate after the experiment following the steps shown in Section 2.4 was collected to test C BA and S BD, and the catalyst was filtered, washed, dried, and reduced for the next cycle experiment. After 5 cycles of experiments, the results of catalytic oxidation experiments are shown in Fig. 10 a. After 5 cycles, the conversion of BA and the selectivity to BD of the catalyst did not undergo a significant decrease. The XRD patterns and SEM images of the used catalyst are shown in Fig. 10b-d. Before and after the reaction, the diffraction peak in the XRD patterns of the catalyst did not change significantly, and the SEM images showed that there was no obvious structural collapse of the catalyst under high temperature and high pressure. In addition, we tested the content of two elements, Ru and Ce, in the post-reaction filtrate using ICP to assess metal leaching. The leaching rate of Ru (Ce) after the reaction was only 2.8 % (1.0 %) by ICP test. Therefore, it can be proved that the reaction is a heterogeneous catalytic reaction. It indicates that the catalyst has good thermal stability. 3.3 Reaction mechanism To further understand the reaction mechanism of BA oxidation to BD, DFT theoretical calculations were performed. Combined with the surface electrostatic potential (ESP) and average localized ionization energy (ALIE) analyses shown in Fig. S3b and Fig. S3d, the hydrogens of α-carbon and hydroxyl groups are the possible reaction sites with oxygen species according to Fig. S3c and Fig. S3e. This is consistent with what has been reported in the literature [62], i.e., the reaction process is a hydrogen atom abstraction process in which the oxygen can draw out the hydrogen atoms from the hydroxyl group and α-carbon, ultimately producing benzaldehyde. A further search for possible transition states (BA-O TS) was performed to give the intrinsic reaction coordinates of the process and estimate the energy potential. According to Fig. 11 a, oxygen can take the hydrogen from the α-carbon and hydroxyl groups by overcoming a potential barrier with an energy of 147.73 kJ mol-1 to ultimately produce benzaldehyde. According to reports [62], the ΔG during hydrogen atom abstraction is negative and the reaction is thermodynamically favorable. Theoretically, the extraction of hydrogen atoms from benzyl alcohol molecules generates benzaldehyde (Fig. 11b). 3.4 Broad-spectrum oxidation capacity The study of loaded ruthenium catalysts for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol has been widely reported [22], and the activity of metallic ruthenium has also been reported for the oxidation of various alcohols to produce the corresponding carbonyl products. The development of catalysts with broad-spectrum selective oxidation capability is urgently needed. Therefore, we designed and developed a Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst and compared the catalytic performance of this catalyst for selective catalytic oxidation of different alcohols to generate the corresponding carbonyl products (aldehydes) (Table 4 ). According to the experimental results, unlike other noble metal catalysts reported, the Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst developed by us is active for the oxidation of various alcohols to generate the corresponding carbonyl products. Meanwhile, the catalyst has high selectivity for catalytic oxidation of various alcohols to generate the corresponding aldehydes. 4 Conclusions In this paper, honeycomb N-doped carbon materials were prepared by hydrothermal reaction and high-temperature carbonization and loaded with Ru-CeO2 bimetal for the selective oxidation of typical alcohols such as benzyl alcohol to synthesize the corresponding carbonyl products. The catalysts with optimal catalytic performance were synthesized by optimizing the synthesis conditions of the catalysts, and the effects of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance were investigated. By controlling the reaction temperature and retention time, benzaldehyde was prevented from being over-oxidized and 100 % selectivity for benzaldehyde was achieved. The Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst showed 85.5 % conversion of benzyl alcohol and 100 % selectivity to benzaldehyde at 140 °C, 6 h, and 2 MPa oxygen pressure. The catalyst still showed high catalytic activity for benzyl alcohol (C BA = 84.7 %) and 100 % selectivity for benzaldehyde through 5-cycle experiments. It indicates that the catalyst has high thermal stability and can resist the high temperature and pressure reaction environment. The formation of benzaldehyde by hydrogen atom abstraction reaction overcoming a potential barrier with an energy of 147.73 kJ·mol-1 is theoretically feasible by DFT calculations. Meanwhile, the catalyst has high activity for the oxidation of various alcohols to form the corresponding aldehydes with broad-spectrum selective oxidation capability. It provides a novel catalyst and a green and economical process pathway for the preparation of corresponding aldehydes by multiphase catalytic oxidation of alcohols. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes by molecular oxygen is one of the most important transformations in multiphase catalysis. In this paper, a catalyst with selective oxidation ability was designed and synthesized for the selective catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. N-doped carbon materials were prepared by high-temperature calcination using hydrothermal reaction products of citric acid and melamine as a carbon source, and a bimetallic catalyst supported by Ru-CeO2 was constructed using the mixture as the carrier for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The results showed that the introduction of CeO2 could effectively improve the oxidizing ability and catalytic activity of the catalyst. The Ru-Ce0.05/NC170–600 catalyst was able to convert 85.5 % benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde at 140 °C, 6 h, and 2 MPa, and the selectivity for benzaldehyde was 100 %. It was demonstrated by DFT that it was theoretically feasible to generate benzaldehyde by extracting hydrogen atoms from benzyl alcohol molecules. Further, the selective oxidation experiments on other alcohols showed that the catalyst has high activity for the oxidation of various alcohols to generate the corresponding carbonyl products, and it is a catalyst with broad-spectrum selective oxidation ability. In this study, a green synthesis route of benzaldehyde was proposed to solve the problems in the traditional process. Meanwhile, it provides a new idea for the synthesis of carbonyl products by selective oxidation of alcohols.
